text: “Do you know \add the\add* time when \add the\add* goats of \add the\add* rocks give birth?
Do you observe \add the\add* doe deer’s giving birth?
Can you number \add the\add* months they fulfill,
and do you know \add the\add* time of its giving birth?
When they crouch, they bring forth their young ones;
they get rid of their labor pains.\f + \fr 39:3 \ft Or “deliver their fetuses” \f*
Their young ones grow strong; they grow up in the open;
they go forth and do not return to them.
“Who has sent forth \add the\add* wild ass free?
And who has released \add the\add* wild donkey’s bonds,
\add to\add* which I have given \add the\add* wilderness \add as\add* its house
and \add the\add* salt flat \add as\add* its dwelling place?
It scorns \add the\add* city’s turmoil;
it does not hear \add the\add* driver’s shouts.
It explores \add the\add* mountains \add as\add* its pasture
and searches after every kind of green plant.
“Is \add the\add* wild ox willing to serve you,
or will he spend the night at your feeding trough?
Can you tie \add the\add* wild ox \add with\add* its rope to a furrow,
or will it harrow \add the\add* valleys after you?
Can you trust it because its strength \add is\add* great,
or will you hand your labor over to it?
Can you rely on it that it will return your grain
and \add that\add* it will gather \add it\add* to your threshing floor?
“\add The\add* wings\f + \fr 39:13 \ft Hebrew “wing” \f* of \add the\add* female ostrich flap\f + \fr 39:13 \ft Or “flaps” \f*—
\add are they\add*\f + \fr 39:13 \ft Or “if,” or “or” \f* \add the\add* pinions of \add the\add* stork or\f + \fr 39:13 \ft Hebrew “and” \f* \add the\add* falcon?
Indeed, it leaves its eggs to the earth,
and it lets \add them\add* be warmed on \add the\add* ground,
and it forgets that a foot might crush an egg,\f + \fr 39:15 \ft Hebrew “it”; or a collective singular (“them”) referring to “eggs” in v. \xt 14 \ft \f*
and ⸤a wild animal⸥\f + \fr 39:15 \ft Literally “an animal of the field” \f* might trample it.\f + \fr 39:15 \ft Or a collective singular (“them”) referring to “eggs” in v. \xt 14 \ft \f*
It deals cruelly with its young ones, as \add if\add* \add they were\add* not its \add own\add*,
as \add if\add* without fear \add that\add* its labor \add were\add* in vain,
because God made it forget wisdom,
and he did not give it a share in understanding.
When it spreads its wings ⸤aloft⸥,\f + \fr 39:18 \ft Literally “in the height” \f*
it laughs at the horse and its rider.
“Do you give power to the horse?
Do you clothe its neck \add with\add* a mane?
Do you make it leap like the locust?
\add The\add* majesty of its snorting \add is\add* terrifying.
They paw in the valley, and it exults with strength;
it goes out to meet \add the\add* battle.
It laughs at danger and is not dismayed,
and it does not turn back from ⸤before⸥\f + \fr 39:22 \ft Literally “from faces of” \f* \add the\add* sword.
Upon it \add the\add* quiver rattles
\add along with\add* \add the\add* flash of \add the\add* spear and \add the\add* short sword.
With roar and rage ⸤it races over the ground⸥,\f + \fr 39:24 \ft Or “it paws \fq the \ft ground”; literally “it swallows \fq the \ft earth/ground” \f*
and it cannot stand still at \add the\add* sound of \add the\add* horn.
⸤Whenever⸥\f + \fr 39:25 \ft Literally “At enough” \f* a horn \add sounds\add*, it says, ‘Aha!’
And it smells \add the\add* battle from a distance—
\add the\add* thunder of \add the\add* commanders and \add the\add* war cry.
“Does \add the\add* hawk soar by your wisdom?
Does it spread its wings to \add the\add* south?
Or does \add the\add* eagle fly high at your command
and construct its nest high?
It lives \add on the\add* rock and spends the night
⸤on the rock point and the mountain stronghold⸥.\f + \fr 39:28 \ft Literally “on \fq the \ft tooth of \fq the \ft rock and \fq the \ft stronghold” \f*
From there it spies out \add the\add* prey;
its eyes look from far away.
And its young ones lick blood greedily,
and where \add the\add* dead carcasses \add are\add*, there they \add are\add*.”
